Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial on the Impact of Cardiovascular Drugs on Myocardial Injury After Noncardiac Surgery

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomised to receive either cardiovascular drugs (aspirin, antihypertensives, statins) or standard care.

Participants.evidence: Participants were adults undergoing noncardiac surgery, with eligibility based on elevated cTn levels within 30 days post-surgery.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomised to receive either cardiovascular drugs (aspirin, antihypertensives, statins) or standard care.

Objective.evidence: This study evaluates the effect of cardiovascular drugs on myocardial injury after noncardiac surgery (MINS).

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the reduction in postoperative mortality within 30 days.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, with allocation concealed using sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was applied to outcome assessors.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 200 participants were randomised: 100 to the intervention group and 100 to the control group.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis included 98 in the intervention group and 97 in the control group, using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the reduction in postoperative mortality within 30 days, with a significant effect size (hazard ratio = 0.75, 95% CI 0.60 to 0.90; p = 0.01).

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were mild, occurring in 3% of the intervention group and 1% of the control group.

Funding.evidence: Funding: Supported by the National Institutes of Health.
